The Eliza M. and Sarah L. Niblack Collection

very large head of the Buddha in cast iron, with downcast eyes and meditative expression. The hair is upswept in neat ridges and tied at the top of the head. The cranial protuberance and extended earlobes are physical attributes that are typical of representations of the Buddha. The surface of the head show seams of the mold in which it was originally cast.
estimated weight of 550 lbs. weight with base is 582 lbs. (10/27/03)
Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Miller in memory of Donald G. Martinelli
Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Miller; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1977.
bronze figurine, Cipollino marble bowl and support

Functioning Cipollino marble fountain. The upper bowl is carved with mermaid and dolphin motif with an octagonal pedestal base. A finely modelled bronze standing fountain figure of "The Verrocchio Boy" holding a dolphin in his arms is situated at the top center of the upper bowl with right leg lifted to the side and bent at the knee slight to the back and the left support leg is on a domed base. The lower bowl, pool-surround is of Sicilian marble exhibiting rounded edges.

approximately 108 x 96 x 96 in. lower bowl: approximately 12 x 96 x 96 in. lower bowl water volume: approximately 20.25 (circumference) x W:2.1 x H:.75 ft. = 31.89 cubic feet upper bowl water volume: approximately 8.5 (circumference) x W:.66 x H:.17 = .95 cubic feet
approximately 246 gallons of water (upper bowl 7 gallons, lower bowl 249 gallons)

Stamped, lower proper right edge of the "E" along the full length: 1 [gapped] [copyright symbol] R INDIANA [in stencilled font] 1970 [HF symbol for Herbert Feuerlicht, Technical Supervisor of Triad Designs] [three stacked lines of smaller text] WORK EXECUTED BY | Lippincott | NORTH HAVEN CONN

06/23/2016 Per Alfred Lippincott, "...technical supervisor, Herbert Feuerlicht, of Triad Designs...this accounts for the large HF that is stamped into the metal just to the left of the Lippincott stamp..."

steel welded sculpture of the word "LOVE" with the "L" stacked on the "V" and the tilted "O" stacked on the "E". Each component was fabricated from 3/16 inch thick sheets of Cor-ten steel. The sheets were cut, welded together and then finished to create hollow, enclosed structures. Each letter is 72 inches deep. Components are secured together by a bolting system. Specifically there are 2 sets of four bolts drilled along the one set and located along the proper left serif of "V" connecting to the upper proper right serif of "E". The other is located at the proper left serif of "L" connecting to the proper right middle of "O". Access panels enable entry for the bolts to be put in place. Once access panel exists along the entire upper surface of the proper left "L" serif; there are two others atop the proper right side of the "E". Central pivot points align the "O" over the "E". Two points about 2-3 inches in height are permanently attached to the "E".
Gift of the Friends of the Indianapolis Museum of Art in memory of Henry F. DeBoest. Restoration was made possible by Patricia J. and James E. LaCrosse.

Inscribed in margin, repeat: THE M.W.P. Co. PAT [illegible character] JAN. 23, 1883.

DATE CREATED: 1883 is based on current reading of the patent date; however, we do not know if the wallpaper was created immediately after the patent was approved, before, or after; the date has also been read as "1881"; so the visible date should read "about 1883" but the Earliest/Latest reflect the manufacturer's active dates.

Although the date is "about 1830," keep "Latest" date as "1880" due to confusions over the original maker and when the dress was made. "about 1830" is the date approved by Textile and Fashion Arts Curator Niloo Paydar in April 2016 based on stylistic qualities of the dress. See Rebecca McNamara's notes in the historical file for more information.

tuple.atom: Eli Lilly and Company Foundation Room
By descent to the artist's widow, Mrs. Kayoko Okada, Tokyo, Japan; purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2011 (TR11137/1).
See Registrar Notes field. Curator's working title, not for distribution: sandstone jali (b), carved wall element of 15.70-15.204 (one of four)
Commissioned in Agra by Lockwood de Forest for Tiffany and de Forest

Sandstone Pierced Screen: This screen consists of carvings from India collected by Mr. Lockwood de Forest and assembled to suggest a palace façade of that country. In Bombay, Ahmedabad, and other Indian cities, are old houses in great number, with elaborate and beautiful carved fronts. Almost the entire upper part of this screen is from such a house front in Ahmedabad. Carvers in India are all of the Mistre or carpenter cast, and all, even the lowest of them in remote villages, seem born with a remarkable instinct for this art. The children begin to learn the trade at three years old. Boys of eight to twelve years carve nearly as well as the men. The details of the carvings evolve as the carver works. Only a few leading lines are sketched on the wood before the cutting begins. Parts of this collection are ancient originals, others are accurate copies made by Indian workmen. Some stone panels, pierced brasses and inlays are also included.
36-7/8 x 24 x 1-1/2 in. 62-3/4 x 30-1/2 x 9 in. (with deck mount)
